sols_html:
\(a\) and \(d\) are orthogonal whenever their dot product is equal to zero. That is,

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = a \cdot d &= \begin{bmatrix} -3 \\ -3 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ k \\ 2k+1 \end{bmatrix}\\ &= (-3)(-1) + (-3)(k) + (3)(2k+1)\\ &= 3 - 3k + 6k+3\\ &= 6 + 3k\\ &= 3(2 + k).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, \(\displaystyle k = -2\) is the value for which \(a\) and \(d\) are orthogonal.

statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} a = \begin{bmatrix} -3 \\ -3 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} \qquad b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} \qquad c = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -4 \\ 12 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Further, let \(d = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ k \\ 2k+1 \end{bmatrix}\) where k is a parameter. Find the value of k for which a and d are orthogonal.
